summary: Email correspondence between Assistant U.S. Attorneys and Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys regarding logistics for reviewing physical evidence and highly confidential materials (including nude/partially nude images seized from Jeffrey Epstein's devices) in preparation for Maxwell's trial. The emails detail negotiations about transporting evidence to 500 Pearl Street, equipment needs, and access for the defense team and Maxwell herself.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Lead defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, corresponding with prosecutors about evidence review logistics and making requests on behalf of the defense team.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Christian R Everdell
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell from Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Bobbi C Sternheim
persons.context: Defense attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell, copied on all correspondence regarding evidence review.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in case 20 Cr. 330, whose defense team is requesting access to evidence for her review and participation in her defense.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier whose residences were searched in 2019, from whose devices the highly confidential images and other evidence were seized.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the case (referenced as AJN - Alison J. Nathan), from whom the defense may need to seek authorization to bring electronic devices into 500 Pearl Street.

connections.description: Menninger is lead defense attorney representing Maxwell in the criminal case, advocating for her access to evidence.
Pagliuca is part of Maxwell's defense team, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Everdell is part of Maxwell's defense team from Cohen & Gresser LLP, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Sternheim is part of Maxwell's defense team, copied on all evidence review correspondence.
Evidence seized from Epstein's residences is relevant to Maxwell's case, indicating their association.

events.title: Scheduled Evidence Review at 500 Pearl Street
events.description: Planned week for defense team and Ghislaine Maxwell to review physical evidence transported to 500 Pearl Street courthouse.

events.title: Scheduled Review of Highly Confidential Images
events.description: Planned week for Maxwell to review approximately 5,507 electronic images and videos marked 'highly confidential' seized from Epstein's devices.

events.title: FBI Searches of Epstein Residences
events.description: FBI conducted searches of Jeffrey Epstein's residences in New York and the U.S. Virgin Islands, seizing electronic devices and other evidence.

events.title: Completion of Responsiveness Review
events.description: FBI completed responsiveness review of images and videos seized from Epstein's devices, identifying highly confidential materials.

locations: 500 Pearl Street, New York, NY (courthouse where evidence review is planned)
FBI Bronx warehouse (where majority of physical evidence is stored)
26 Federal Plaza, New York, NY (FBI office where some cash evidence items are located)
St. Andrew's Plaza, New York, NY 10007 (U.S. Attorney's Office address)
MDC (Metropolitan Detention Center, where Maxwell was held and previously reviewed some evidence)
keyFacts: The FBI seized dozens of electronic devices from Jeffrey Epstein's residences in 2019, including desktop computers, servers, and laptops.
There are approximately 2,100 electronic images and videos seized from Epstein's devices designated as 'highly confidential' that had not been previously provided to the defense as of March 2021.
Physical evidence includes massage tables, cash items, plaster busts of female torsos, a stuffed dog, framed pictures, and electronic devices that cannot be turned on.
The defense team requested to review evidence with 8 attorneys/investigators present along with Maxwell, requiring special arrangements for privacy and equipment.
Prosecutors confirmed that neither AUSAs nor agents would record or attempt to record any part of the evidence review or conversations among the defense team.
